If the coefficients are A = [0] and B = [1;-1], this represents a simple finite impulse response (FIR) filter that computes the first difference of the input signal. Specifically, the filter output at time t is given by:

y(t) = x(t) - x(t-1)

In other words, the filter computes the difference between the current sample and the previous sample of the input signal. This can be useful for detecting sudden changes or spikes in the input signal, as it effectively high-pass filters the input signal.

In terms of the expected output graph, the filter will tend to emphasize high-frequency components of the input signal, while attenuating low-frequency components. The specific shape of the output graph will depend on the characteristics of the input signal. If the input signal contains sudden changes or spikes, the filter output will tend to be larger at those points in time, while if the input signal is relatively smooth, the filter output will be relatively small.

Visually, the output signal will likely contain a mix of positive and negative spikes that correspond to changes in the input signal. The spacing and amplitude of these spikes will depend on the specific characteristics of the input signal and the filter coefficients. Overall, the filter is useful for detecting sudden changes in the input signal and can be a useful tool for data analysis and signal processing.
